Graphical abstract Zn, Ce or Ni metal was doped on mesoporous rod-like Al2O3 prepared by using cationic surfactant cetyl-trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) assisted hydrothermal method for in-situ catalytic upgrading of bio-oil derived from the fast pyrolysis of sunflower stalk. The morphology, crystal structure, surface area, reduction behaviour and acidity of the as-prepared catalyst were characterized. Uniform rod-like γ-Al2O3 particles with a surface area as high as 412m2/g and an average mesopore diameter of 3.51nm were obtained at a CTAB/Al molar ratio of 0.5 and Zn, Ce or Ni metal was found to be able to homogeneously disperse on it. The catalysts with 2.5wt.% metal (Zn, Ce or Ni) loading amount exhibited the high catalytic activity and selectivity for upgrading of bio-oil with high content of oxygenated components to aromatic hydrocarbons, especially benzene, toluene and xylene (BTX). The total relative maximum hydrocarbon amount of 92% in the upgraded bio-oil was obtained by using 2.5wt.% Ni/Al2O3. Four-cycle reusability test indicated that the metal-doped microporous rod-like γ-Al2O3 alumina catalysts had long-term stability in their performance. Moreover, the regeneration of spent catalysts (4th reuse) by calcination at 650°C in air for 30min recovered their activity perfectly. It is expected that such metal-doped rod-like alumina catalysts can be applied as bio-oil upgrading catalysts in a practical process. Keywords Mesoporous alumina Metal doping Catalytic upgrading Bio-oil Aromatic hydrocarbon 1 Introduction Nowadays, with the rapid consumption of fossil fuel resources and the expanding energy demand, biomass is considered as one of alternative and green energy resources due to its sustainable and renewable property [1]. Thermochemical technologies such as torrefaction, gasification and pyrolysis have been developed for the conversion of biomass to fuels [2]. Fast pyrolysis is an effective way to produce bio-oil from biomass. However, pyrolysis bio-oil always contains a large amount of oxygenated compounds such as acids, ketones, phenols, alcohols, aldehydes, sugars and others, and cannot be applied directly in the engine and other machines. It needs to be upgraded by converting oxygenated compounds to hydrocarbons to increase its heating value and chemical stability [3]. To date, various upgrading techniques have been developed. Hydro-deoxygenation (HDO) is a catalytic hydrotreating process by using hydrogen under high pressure [4]. However, the consumption of a large amount of hydrogen and high operation pressure increases the cost in an industrial process. To solve this problem, upgrading of bio-oil using solid acid catalysts such as zeolites at ambient pressure was proposed [5]. Veses et al. [2] found that HZSM-5 is good catalyst with high activity for the removal of oxygen element in oxygenated compounds, producing rich aromatic hydrocarbons in the upgraded bio-oil. However, the small micropore structure with a pore size of 5.1Å×5.6Å limits large oxygenated compounds in bio-oil entering [6]. Mochizuki et al. [7] found that rapid catalyst deactivation easily occurs for the zeolites with relatively small pores owing to the pore blockage by coke deposition. Moreover, many unwanted polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons such as naphthalene and phenanthrene are also easily generated on such zeolite catalysts. Mesoporous materials have been considered as the most promising and alternative catalysts for upgrading bio-oil [8]. The large pores in these materials can provide enough mass transfer channels for reactants and products, avoiding the pore blockage due to the possible coking and molecule polymerization. Lu et al. [9] found that mesoporous ZrO2 and TiO2 based catalysts can effectively transform oxygenated compounds such as phenols, sugars and acids with large molecular sizes to hydrocarbons via cracking and deoxygenating reactions such as dehydration, decarboxylation and decarbonylation. However, due to the low surface area (∼80m2/g), the highest hydrocarbon content in the upgraded bio-oil was only 13%. To solve this problem, mesoporous silica with high surface area (∼280m2/g) was applied so that the hydrocarbon content in the upgraded bio-oil was increased up to 23.4% [7]. To achieve higher hydrocarbon content, various transition metals such as Co, Ni, Zn, Fe, Ga and Mo and some noble metals such as Pd, Pt and Ru have been doped on catalyst supports for adjusting the acidity and promoting deoxygenation effectivity and an improving anti-coking ability [10]. Vichaphund et al. [11] found that the metal loaded on HZSM-5 had higher ability for the generation of monocyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (MAHs) such as benzene, toluene and xylenes (BTX) via oligomerization and aromatization. Wang et al. [12] modified catalyst by Zn to improve the coking resistance property. In our previous work [13], Cu was loaded on mesoporous MCM-41 and KIT-6 materials for the upgrading of bio-oil. It is found that these mesoporous catalysts with pore size in the range from 2 to 5nm exhibited a high selectivity to aromatic hydrocarbons (∼85%). Due to the large pore size, some lignin-derived oxygenated compounds were found to be also effectively transformed to monocyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (MAHs). γ-Al2O3 should also be one of the most effective catalyst and catalyst support for the upgrading of bio-oil owing to its high surface area, large pore size and high acidity for pre-cracking of large bio-oil molecules. However, direct application of traditional γ-Al2O3 always results in severe coke formation, leading to the deactivation of catalyst. To date, only a few studies on metal-loaded γ-Al2O3 for the catalytic upgrading of bio-oil have been reported [14,15]. In this study, mesoporous rod-like γ-Al2O3 was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis method, in which cationic surfactant cetyl-trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) was applied to control the morphology, surface area, and pore size by adjusting CTAB/Al molar ratios. Three kinds of metals, i.e., Zn, Ce and Ni were separately doped on the as-prepared γ-Al2O3 for in-situ catalytic upgrading of bio-oil derived from the fast pyrolysis of sunflower stalk. The objective of this study is to improve the performance of mesoporous γ-Al2O3 based catalysts in term of effective converting oxygenated compounds to hydrocarbons, especially aromatic hydrocarbons and reducing the coke deposition on the catalyst during reaction. It is expected that high hydrocarbon amount can be obtained in the upgraded bio-oil by using these catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Biomass materials Dried sunflower stalk particles with a size of 1–2.8mm was used as biomass feedstock in this study. The proximate and ultimate analysis results and ash compositions of this biomass were reported elsewhere [19]. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Mesoporous alumina was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis with initial molar compositions: 1.0Al: 0.1-0.75CTAB: 5.28urea: 70 H2O. In a typical synthesis process, 10.72g of Al(NO3)3·9H2O (Wako, Japan) and 9.06g of urea (Wako, Japan) were dissolved in 36mL of deionized water under vigorous stirring at 35°C for 30min. Then, a certain amount of CTAB (Wako, Japan) was added into the solution and remained at 35°C under vigorous stirring until homogeneous solution was formed. The mixture was then poured into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 120°C for 24h. Finally, the white precipitate was filtered, washed with deionized water, dried at 105°C in oven and then calcined at 750°C in air for 2h. The mesoporous alumina sample was denoted as Al2O3-X, where X represents the molar ratio of CTAB/Al. Metal (Zn, Ce or Ni)-doped Al2O3 was prepared by impregnation method. In a typical impregnation process, a certain amount of as-prepared Al2O3 powder was added into the aqueous solutions of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, Ce(NO3)3·6H2O or Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (Wako, Japan) and stirred at room temperature for 2h. Thereafter, the slurry was dried at 80°C, followed by calcination at 650°C in air for 2h. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Specific surface area (BET method), pore volume and mesopore size distributions (BJH method) of the catalyst were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption which conducted at −196°C using a Quantachrome instrument (NOVA 4200e, USA). XRD pattern was determined by a X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku Smartlab, Japan) in the 2θ range of 30−90° with a scanning step of 0.02° using Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.1542nm). Surface morphology of catalyst was observed with a scanning electron microscope (SEM, SU8010, Hitachi, Japan) coupled with energy dispersive X-ray detector (EDX). Reduction behaviour and acidity of the catalyst were carried out by H2-Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and NH3-Temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), respectively, using a BET-CAT catalyst analyzer (BEL, Japan). Before H2-TPR and NH3-TPD measurements, all samples were preheated at 750°C for 1h under He flow for removal of moisture and some impurities within sample structure. The amount of coke deposited on catalyst after reaction was determined using a thermogravimatric analyzer (TGA, DTG-60H, Shimadzu, Japan) with a heating rate of 10°C/min until a temperature of 800°C under air flow. 2.4 In-situ catalytic upgrading of bio-oil The schematic diagram of the experimental setup for in-situ catalytic upgrading of bio-oil derived from the fast pyrolysis of biomass was reported elsewhere [13]. In a typical run, 0.1g of biomass particles and 0.6g of catalyst powders were separately packed with quartz wool in the fixed bed reactor. During the reaction N2 gas flow (100cm3/min) was used as the carrier gas. Prior to the experiment, reactor was purged by N2 gas flow for about 10min in order to move out the inside air. The fast pyrolysis reaction temperature, reaction time and heating rate were fixed at 565°C, 4min and 1000°C/min, respectively, which are the optimum conditions to obtain the highest bio-oil yield in our preliminary experiments. The liquid product was trapped by acetone in ice-cooling bottle and the non-condensed gas was purified and collected in a gas bag for further analysis. 2.5 Analysis of bio-oil and gas products The obtained bio-oil was analyzed by using a gas chromatography (GC-2010 Plus, Shimadzu, Japan)/mass spectrometry (GCMS-QP2010 Ultra, Shimadzu, Japan) with Ultra ALLOY+ 5 capillary column. The bio-oil sample was automatically injected into the column whose temperature was increased from 50 to 300°C with a ramp rate 10°C/min and hold at 300°C for 10min. The ionization chamber of MS setup was set at 200°C. Various peaks in chromatogram corresponding to various compounds such as aromatics, aliphatics, ketones, phenols sugars, acids, aldehydes, furan and others were identified by comparison with the built-in NIST spectral library. Here, the products with boiling points lower than 300°C can be detected. In addition, the peak area percentages obtained from GC–MS chromatogram were considered to be a good estimation because it implies the concentration of products in bio-oil. The water content in bio-oil was measured using Karl-Fisher Titration method (MKS-500, KEM, Japan). The collected non-condensed gas was analyzed off-line using a gas chromatography (Agilent 7890A GC system, USA) equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and 3 packed columns (1 molecular sieve 5A column+1 HayeSep Q column+1 molecular sieve 5A column) for separation of CO, CH4 and CO2 using He as a carrier gas, while a molecular sieve 5A for H2 detection using Ar as a carrier gas. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of catalyst N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of alumina samples prepared with different molar ratios of CTAB to Al are shown in Fig. 1 A. One can see that all the samples exhibit IUPAC type IV isotherms with a hysteresis loop above 0.4P/P0, which is the typical characteristics of mesoporous material. The isotherm of the obtained Al2O3 without using CTAB exhibits a loop shape, which is classified as the type H-3 with slit-shaped pores. Interestingly, for the Al2O3 prepared with the assistance of CTAB, the type H-2 hysteresis loop in the isotherm is obtained, indicating the existence of ink-bottle mesoporous structure [16]. Fig. 1B shows pore-size distributions of Al2O3 samples. It can be seen that in the presence of CTAB during the synthesis, a narrow pore size distribution with uniform pore size of about 3.4nm can be obtained. The textural properties of catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . One can see that the Al2O3 sample prepared without CTAB assistance has the lowest surface area and the smallest pore size. In contrast, in the presence of CTAB, the surface area and pore volume of the obtained Al2O3 sample increase with the increase in the molar ratio of CTAB/Al until 0.5, but with the further increase of the molar ratio of CTAB/Al, the surface area remains almost unchanged and pore volume and size decrease, indicating that the optimum molar ratio of CTAB/Al should be 0.5 in this study. Thus, Al2O3-0.5 was used for further investigation. Furthermore, as shown in Table 1, the surface areas and pore diameters of all catalysts decrease a little after metal is doped it, indicating that some surfaces and pore of Al2O3 are covered or occupied by the dispersed metal species. As shown in Fig. 2 , the diffractogram of Al2O3-0.5 sample exhibits some broad crystalline peaks around 35–40°, especially at 45° and 67° which are ascribed to the reflections on (400) and (440) crystal planes of the cubic γ-Al2O3 phase [17]. It should be noted that the diffraction peak intensities of Al2O3-0.5 are weak, indicating that the use of CTAB to modify in the Al2O3 porous structure could retard the crystallization to some extent [18]. Interestingly, after metal is doped on Al2O3-0.5, the diffraction intensities increase due to the incorporation between loaded metal with Al2O3 structure [19]. Moreover, one can see that some new phases, i.e., ZnAl2O4, CeAlO3, NiAl2O4 are also observed in spite of no appearance of diffraction peaks attributed to metal species of Zn, Ce and Ni. It indicates that metal species should be well distributed on Al2O3 structure, which could lead to the reduction of sintering, accumulation and deactivation during the thermal reactions [19]. Fig. 3 shows SEM images of various catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3A, in the absence of CTAB during synthesis, broken-sheep-wool-like γ-Al2O3 particles can be obtained. In contrast, with the assistance of CTAB, uniform rod-like γ-Al2O3 particles with smooth surface are obtained (Fig. 3B). It is possible that when CTAB is added in the reactants, CTAB serves as template to hinder the movement and diffusion of reactants, leading to the formation of new nucleis and evolution of rod-like morphology. Here, it should be noted that urea is also added in the reactants as slow precipitant in the system, in which urea would be decomposed to NH3 and CO2 and then react with Al3+ to form Al(OH)3 and/or AlOOH. In the presence of urea, CTAB molecules would have enough time to be absorbed on the surface of aluminum hydroxyl particles, and induce them to form specific morphological structure [20]. Fig. 3C–E shows SEM images of 2.5wt.% metal doped Al2O3 particles. It can be seen that the surface of γ-Al2O3 particles becomes hairy, which may provide more surface area and more active sites for the upgrading of bio-oil on the catalyst surface, leading to the enhancement of its catalytic activity. Fig. 4 shows TPR profiles of 2.5wt.% metal doped Al2O3 catalysts. The reduction peaks at high temperature range indicate the existences of metal oxides, i.e., ZnO, CeO2 and NiO on Al2O3. Compared with pure metal oxides in the literature [20,21], the reduction peaks appear at higher temperature. This is due to the strong interaction of metal oxide on support. Moreover, it should be noted that the doped metal oxides could not be completely reduced even at a temperature as high as 850°C due to their well dispersion and the existences of those new phases of ZnAl2O4, CeAlO3, NiAl2O4. In addition, multiple reduction peaks are also found since the different states of metal oxides exist on supports with high dispersion and strong interaction with the porous structure of Al2O3 [22]. Fig. 5 shows NH3-TPD profiles of catalyst before and after reactions. It can be seen that Al2O3 desorbs NH3 in a wide temperature range of 150–500°C. Interestingly, as shown in Fig. 5 and Table 1, after the 1–10wt.% Zn were loaded on Al2O3, the acidities of catalysts are clearly enhanced with an increase of area of NH3-desorption peak can be observed. Moreover, comparing with pure Al2O3, the position of NH3 desorption peak also slightly changes. This should be attributed to the interaction and substitution of proton sites on Al2O3 structure with the doping Zn species, resulting in the regeneration of new proton sites on catalyst [6,8,10,12]. As obtained, the acidity was significantly increased from 0.287 to 0.329mmol/g with the increase in Zn loading amount from 1 to 2.5wt.%. In contrast, when the loading amount was increased more, i.e., 5 and 10wt.% of Zn loading amounts, the acidity decreased to some extent, resulting from the covering of acid sites by the generated ZnO cluster. In addition, metal dispersion efficiency on the support could be influenced by the metal loading amount. It demonstrates that the low Zn loading amount such as 1 or 2.5wt.% should be well dispersed and incorporated on Al2O3 structure, which could lead to the easy formation of ZnAl2O4 with the improvement of rich acidity. Thus, the similar optimum loading amount of 2.5wt.% was also applied for Ce or Ni loaded Al2O3-0.5. As shown in Table 1, 2.5wt.%Ce/Al2O3-0.5 and 2.5wt.%Ni/Al2O3-0.5 have similar amounts of acidity about 0.3mmol/g which were quite similar with 2.5wt.%Zn/Al2O3, indicating that three kinds of metals used in this study had the similar improvement of the acidic property of Al2O3. Here, it should be noted that high acidity is benefit for the conversion of oxygenated compounds in bio-oil to hydrocarbons via deoxygenation reactions. 3.2 Catalytic upgrading of bio-oil In this study, a fixed bed reactor was applied and in this case, the residence time of pyrolysis bio-oil in the catalyst layer should have great effect on the conversion. Here, the biomass amount was fixed, and the increase of catalyst amount on the final the upgrading efficiency was investigated by using pure Al2O3 as the catalyst at first. As shown in Fig. 6 , one can see that the relative total hydrocarbon amount increases obviously with the increase in the catalyst/biomass weight ratio until the highest value of 52.9% at the catalyst/biomass weight ratio of 8. More catalyst amount can provide more active sites for the deoxygenation and cracking, and increase the residence time of bio-oil passing through it. However, the total relative hydrocarbon amount decreases a little when the catalyst/biomass weight ratio is over 8, probably due to the promoting of secondary reactions, by which hydrocarbon molecules are further cracked into gases, coke and others during the long residence time. Thus, the catalyst/biomass weight ratio was set at 8 in this study and applied for further studies. Fig. 7 A shows relative amounts of chemical compositions in the bio-oils obtained by using various Al2O3-X catalysts with different CTAB/Al molar ratios. Herein, the chemicals in the product are classified into nine groups, i.e., aromatic hydrocarbons, aliphatic hydrocarbons, phenols, ketones, aldehydes, furans, sugars, acids and other. Among them, the relative total amount of aromatic and aliphatic hydrocarbons in the upgraded bio-oil is used as the indicator for identifying upgrading efficiency. In the presence of various Al2O3, the relative total hydrocarbon amount increases obviously while the oxygenated compounds, especially sugars, phenols, ketones and acids, in the upgraded bio-oil decreases, indicating that those deoxygenation reactions such as decarboxylation, dehydration, decarbonylation, oligomerization, isomerization, dehydroxylation and dehydrogenation occur on the catalysts [23]. One can see that from Al2O3-0.1 to Al2O3-0.5, the relative total hydrocarbon amount in the upgraded bio-oil increases dramatically from 57 to 67%. It should be attributed to the increase of surface area and pore size, which result in the increasing of active sites and reducing of mass transfer resistance. For these catalysts, oxygenated compounds in the bio-oil can more easily diffuse in the mesopores and reach the active sites and convert to hydrocarbons. It is observed that sugars and acids in upgraded bio-oil are almost disappear in the presence of Al2O3-X catalysts. In general, sugars in the bio-oil can be deoxygenated via a two-step process: (I) levoglucosan is converted into furans via dehydration reaction and then, (II) aromatic hydrocarbons are formed continuously by converting the furans via dehydration and decarboxylation reactions [24]. Meanwhile, the acids can be easily converted into CO and CO2 via decarboxylation and decarboxylation reactions. Fig. 7B shows the distribution of aromatic hydrocarbons in the upgraded bio-oil by using various Al2O3-X catalysts. Herein, the aromatic hydrocarbons are classified into seven groups, i.e., benzene, toluene, xylenes, ethylbenzene, indenes, naphthalenes and others. Among them, BTX groups are the more desired components in the upgraded bio-oil since they are the major petrochemical compounds, which can increase the octane value in gasoline and be widely used as other fuel precursors. As shown in Fig. 7B, Al2O3-X (X=0.1–0.75) shows much higher selectivity for MAHs production when compared with Al2O3, and by them, only a little amount of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), i.e., indenes, naphthalenes, fluorene, phenanthrene and anthracene are obtained. It indicates that the pore size has great effect on the final products and the mesoporous Al2O3 with a pore size of about 3nm can facilitate the production of smaller aromatic hydrocarbon molecules. Here, Al2O3-0.5 was selected as the catalyst and catalyst support for further investigation. Fig. 8 shows the effect of Zn loading amount (1, 2.5, 5 and 10wt.%) on Al2O3-0.5 for the upgrading of bio-oil. One can see that when Zn is loaded on Al2O3-0.5 and used for the bio-oil upgrading, the relative total hydrocarbon amount in the upgraded bio-oil increases obviously, especially, the selectivity to the aromatic hydrocarbons is greatly increased. The relative total hydrocarbon amount in the upgraded bio-oil is increased from 81.6 to 90.5% with the increase in Zn loading amount from 1 to 2.5wt.%, but decreased to some extent with the further increase of Zn loading amount, indicating the optimum Zn loading amount in this study should be 2.5wt.%. As indicated above, the overloading of Zn amount could result in the sintering of metal during the thermal reaction process, leading to the reduction of catalytic performance for the conversion of oxygenated compounds into hydrocarbons. In addition, it could decrease the surface area and pore size of the catalyst so that the mass transfer resistance increases. Fig. 9 shows mass balance of the products and gas yields derived from in situ catalytic upgrading of bio-oil using Zn (1, 2.5, 5 and 10wt.%)/Al2O3-0.5 catalysts. One can see that the yields of carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide and water are increased obviously in the presence of catalysts, which are corresponded with the relative total hydrocarbon amounts in the upgraded bio-oil. It also clearly indicates that some deoxygenation reactions such as dehydration, dehydrogenation and decarboxylation, decarbonylation occurred. Moreover, since 2.5wt.% Zn loading amount presented the highest catalytic upgrading of bio-oil, for further comparison, this optimum amount was also applied with Ce and Ni loadings. Fig. 10 A compares chemical compositions in upgraded bio-oil by using 2.5wt.% metal (Zn, Ce and Ni) loaded Al2O3-0.5. One can see that three catalysts exhibit the similar catalytic activity by an increasing of hydrocarbons with a decreasing of oxygenated compounds. The relative total maximum hydrocarbon amount of 92%, which includes the aromatic hydrocarbon of 82.9% and the aliphatic hydrocarbon of 9.1%, was obtained by using 2.5wt.%Ni/Al2O3-0.5. As shown in Fig. 5 and Table 1, these three catalysts show the similar pore structures and acidity, which can be considered as the main factors to affect the catalytic performance. For 2.5wt.%Ce/Al2O3-0.5, it presents the lowest catalytic activity when compared with other two, which should be attributed to it’s the lowest acidity. Fig. 10B shows the distribution of aromatic hydrocarbons in the upgraded bio-oil. One can see that both 2.5wt.%Ce/Al2O3-0.5 and 2.5wt.%Ni/Al2O3-0.5 show high selectivity towards MAHs, and the selectivity of aromatic compounds in the upgraded bio-oil is in the order of benzene>toluene>xylenes>ethylbenzene>others>indenes>naphthalenes. It indicated that Ce and Ni retarded the alkylation and aromatization of benzene for PAHs formation. In contrast, for 2.5wt.%Zn/Al2O3-0.5, the order becomes to toluene>benzene>others>naphthalenes>xylenes>ethylbenzene>indenes, indicating that Zn favoured in promoting the alkylation with MAHs to form PAHs. In addition, it is possible that many protons were available inside Zn-doped Al2O3 with the adsorbed carbenium, resulting in the enhancement of aromatic production via aromatization, Diels–Alder reaction and oligomerization. Here, it should be noted that the aromatic hydrocarbons (C5 to C12) produced in this study are also contained in gasoline. The possible mechanism for the aromatic hydrocarbons formation from the catalytic upgrading of bio-oil over these catalysts is proposed in Fig. 11 . The reactions in the reactor should occur (I) within the solid biomass, (II) over the catalyst and (III) in the gas phase. In general, the reactions occurred during pyrolysis of biomass is complex. Biomass should be firstly pyrolyzed and decomposed into many oxygenated compounds such as anhydrosugars, acids, furans, and phenols. Then, these intermediate oxygenated compounds diffuse into the catalyst layer, and contact with the active sites on the surfaces and within the pores of catalyst, leading to the conversion into smaller hydrocarbon fragments “hydrocarbon pool” via some reactions such as dehydration and re-arrangement, cracking, dehydration and decarbonylation [25]. Here, it is considered that the C2–C4 alkenes or alkynes are converted to the cyclic aliphatic hydrocarbons via combination at first, and then further converted aromatic hydrocarbons via Diels–Alder reaction, aromatization, oligomerization, and cyclization. Meanwhile, MAHs and their reactions with oxygenates lead to the formation of naphthalenes and other PAHs. In this study, the loading of metal on alumina can promote Lewis acid sites or electron pair acceptors, and the hydride ions release can promote the transformation of olefins to carbenium ions through intermediate dienes [8]. Simultaneously, coke could be formed on the catalyst by decomposition of gas phase and polycondensation of aromatics, furans and phenols or by re-polymerization and/or secondary pyrolysis. 3.3 Catalyst reusability The reusability of four catalysts, i.e., Al2O3-0.5, 2.5wt.%Zn/Al2O3-0.5, 2.5wt.%Ce/Al2O3-0.5 and 2.5wt.%Ni/Al2O3-0.5, were tested for 5 cycles at the same operation conditions. From the first cycle until the fourth cycle, the spent catalysts were reused without regeneration, but for the fifth cycle, they were regenerated at first by calcination of them at 650°C for 30min under air atmosphere. As shown in Fig. 12 , for Al2O3-0.5 without metal loading, the catalytic performance for the upgrading of bio-oil decrease obviously in the reuse cycle. In contrast, for the metal loaded Al2O3-0.5, no serious reduction on the hydrocarbon amount in upgrade bio-oil is observed. As shown in Table 2 and Fig. 9, more coke was formed on the pure Al2O3-0.5, which could cover the active sites and make pores blockage, leading to the rapid deactivation of catalyst. In contrast, metal loading on it reduced coking formation. Metal species might promote hydrogen atom migration through CH activation which assists to catalyze the oligomerization of intermediates, leading to the preservation of catalyst by preventing coke formation on the surface of catalyst [10,12]. Interestingly, at the first reuse cycle, all metal loaded catalysts present the increase of hydrocarbon amount when compared with the fresh catalysts, indicating that the reused catalysts have better catalytic activity than the fresh ones. This should be attributed to the contribution of alkali metal or alkaline earth metal (AAEM) species such K and Ca on the spent catalyst, which are derived from the pyrolysis of sunflower [19,26]. Fig. 13 shows element mappings of spent catalysts, on which the existence of K species on the surface of catalyst are obviously observed. It is reported that AAEM species can promote some deoxgenation reactions to remove oxygen from the bio-oil [27]. Also, AAEM species can assist the elimination of coke on catalyst as follows [28]: (1) K2CO3 +2C→2K+3CO (2) K2O-C+H2O→K2O2-C+H2 (3) αK2O2-C+αC→αK2O-C+αCO (4) (1−α)K2O2-C+(1−α)CO→(1−α)K2O-C+(1−α)CO2 (5) Overall reaction: αC+H2O→H2 +(1−α)CO2 +(2α−1)CO here the complicated potassium intermediates such as K2O-C and K2O2-C could also dominate the catalytic process. Furthermore, the two redox cycles of K2CO3 promote the carbon elimination. This may be also one of the reasons why these catalysts exhibit the good reusability even without regeneration. Another reason can be revealed to phenomenon of coke deposition amount on catalysts with different metal loadings and without metal loading. DTG thermograms of spent catalysts after reaction (4th reuse) are shown in Fig. 14 . One can see that the derivative weight loss peak of spent catalysts appears at the different temperature ranges, indicating that the states of coke on the different catalyst are different. It is reported that different temperature ranges for burning out of coke depend on the coke deposition position, coke structure and coke particle size [29–31]. Here, the coke formed on Ce/Al2O3-0.5 is more easily removed. In contrast, the cokes formed on Zn or Ni/Al2O3-0.5 are difficult to be moved out. The higher peak is observed for pure Al2O3-0.5 catalyst, indicating more coke can be formed on it. The NH3-TPD profiles and acidities of spent catalysts of 2.5wt.%Zn/Al2O3-0.5, 2.5wt.%Ce/Al2O3-0.5 and 2.5wt.%Ni/Al2O3-0.5 after regeneration were also investigated. As shown in Fig. 5 and Table 1, the acidities of spent catalysts after regeneration are decreased a little, indicating that its catalytic activity can be perfectly recovered. Here, it should be noted that some impurities such as AAEM species from the biomass on the spent catalysts could affect the acidity of the regenerated catalyst. Fig. 12 also shows that the upgrading performances of all spent metal loaded catalysts are successfully recovered by regeneration. In contrast, the performance of spent pure Al2O3-0.5 cannot be well recovered. It indicates the importance of metal loading on such a kind of support. 4 Conclusions In this study, mesoporous rod-like alumina with controllable pore size was successfully prepared by hydrothermal synthesis with the assistance of CTAB. The initial molar ratio of CTAB/Al of 0.5 was selected as the optimum one for synthesis of mesoporous Al2O3 with high surface area and large pore size, which is suitable for the catalytic upgrading of bio-oil. The effect of metal loading amount on the catalytic performance was also investigated and 2.5wt.% loading amount was found to be the best one with higher acidity, by which the relative total hydrocarbon amount in the upgraded bio-oil was greatly increased. Especially, 2.5wt.%Zn/Al2O3-0.5 and 2.5wt.%Ni/Al2O3-0.5 showed high selectivity towards MAHs. It is also found that 2.5wt.% metal (Zn, Ce or Ni)/Al2O3-0.5 catalysts exhibited excellent reusability and can be regenerated completely after several reuse cycles. It is expected that these catalysts can be widely applied for the upgrading of bio-oil in a practical process. coredata.dc:description: Zn, Ce or Ni metal was doped on mesoporous rod-like Al2O3 prepared by using cationic surfactant cetyl-trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) assisted hydrothermal method for in-situ catalytic upgrading of bio-oil derived from the fast pyrolysis of sunflower stalk. The morphology, crystal structure, surface area, reduction behaviour and acidity of the as-prepared catalyst were characterized. Uniform rod-like γ-Al2O3 particles with a surface area as high as 412m2/g and an average mesopore diameter of 3.51nm were obtained at a CTAB/Al molar ratio of 0.5 and Zn, Ce or Ni metal was found to be able to homogeneously disperse on it. The catalysts with 2.5wt.% metal (Zn, Ce or Ni) loading amount exhibited the high catalytic activity and selectivity for upgrading of bio-oil with high content of oxygenated components to aromatic hydrocarbons, especially benzene, toluene and xylene (BTX). The total relative maximum hydrocarbon amount of 92% in the upgraded bio-oil was obtained by using 2.5wt.% Ni/Al2O3. Four-cycle reusability test indicated that the metal-doped microporous rod-like γ-Al2O3 alumina catalysts had long-term stability in their performance. Moreover, the regeneration of spent catalysts (4th reuse) by calcination at 650°C in air for 30min recovered their activity perfectly. It is expected that such metal-doped rod-like alumina catalysts can be applied as bio-oil upgrading catalysts in a practical process.
coredata.dc:title: Selectively catalytic upgrading of bio-oil to aromatic hydrocarbons over Zn, Ce or Ni-doped mesoporous rod-like alumina catalysts
